name: Expense_Management.xlsx
data: Cash advances are strictly prohibited. The policy states: 'CASH/TRAVEL ADVANCE functionality is not available via the corporate card OR via Accounts Payable or any other method. ANY travel/cash advance is strictly prohibited.'

Best practice is that all spend must be on a company corporate card.  For reasons that the company corporate card is not available or an option.....Temporary cash advances are the least effective means of paying for travel and related expenses for several reasons, including negative float, lack of management information, administrative cost and lack of quality receipts. If cash advances are permitted from a company cash float/petty cash, (i) the policy must indicate the amount limit and approval requirements to obtain cash prior to trip departure.  (ii) The policy will provide limits for daily and per trip cash withdrawal amounts. (iii)  Companies must outline required documentation for cash advance receipts and Company will outline scenario/example of when cash advances would be applicable (i.e. tipping).
The policy states that limo charges should not be directly billed to Gartner. Car service receipts will be emailed, faxed or mailed directly to the traveler.

The principal advantage offered by central bills or direct invoices is that they are convenient for employees. The principal disadvantages of central bills/direct invoices are that the organization retains 100% liability and they require extensive human intervention to match expense report details to the central bill/direct invoice. (i) If central billing or direct billing is permitted, the policy will indicate the procedures and approval required to establish a central bill/direct invoice for a travel-related vendor and the back-up documentation required for                                                                                              submission with the employee's travel expense form.  (ii) The best practice is to deny the use of central bills or direct invoices under any circumstance for travel-related expenses.

Rating is Partial Because: Policy only mentions limo charges but does not comprehensively address central billing/direct invoice procedures.Content: Need to add procedures and approval requirements for establishing central bill/direct invoice for all travel-related vendors.

All Gartner Associates must apply for a corporate credit card within 30 days of hire if traveling on company business two or more times a year or expensing >$250/yr in approved business expenses. The corporate credit card must be used for all Gartner-approved travel business expenses.

A corporate charge card is the only payment vehicle that enables an organization to take an integrated approach to travel expense management. The benefits of a corporate charge card system include improved information management, cash management, and reduced administrative costs.  If a corporate card program is in place, (i) the policy will provide the name of the program vendor and/or a link to program details (contact information, etc.).  (ii) The best practice is to mandate the use of the company-sponsored corporate card for all travel and entertainment expenses.
Corporate T&E Card Enrollment Guidelines and Application Instructions

The policy provides enrollment instructions stating that new associates with need to travel should apply for the card very soon after joining. Guidance is available from intranet on how to apply for a new corporate card.

The policy states: (i)  specific criteria for card issuance, e.g. provide a Corporate Charge Card to any employee who travels more than once a year, or who incurs local meal and entertainment expenses (minimum dollar amount can be specified).  (ii) Enrollment instructions must include a copy of the application form, or an on-line link/inclusion in appendix, and procedures for completion and approval.
Personal Use of Corporate Payment Card
Personal charges on corporate card are strictly prohibited. The policy states that personal or non-reimbursable expenses are not to be charged on corporate credit card.

The policy states: (i) the Corporate Card must be used for business related expenses only and personal usage specifically prohibited.  (ii)  In the event that personal travel is combined with business, the policy will instruct employees to have any personal charges billed to a personal credit card (or paid by cash from personal funds) by the hotel, etc.
If your card is lost/stolen, you must report it immediately to the card company and obtain a replacement card.
(i) The policy should provide procedures and detailed contact information regarding how and when to report a lost or stolen corporate card and how to obtain a replacement card.

Rating is Null Because: Policy lacks specific contact information and detailed procedures.Content: Need to add specific contact numbers, websites and step-by-step procedures for reporting lost/stolen cards and obtaining replacements.

Associates are responsible for maintaining the card in good standing by submitting expense reports within 15 days of incurring a charge. Credit card accounts unpaid after due date will incur late charges and be placed in Delinquent Credit Card Balance process.

(i) The policy should explain the payment responsibility of the traveler, i.e.., instructions to remit payment promptly upon receipt of the monthly statement and outline suspension and cancellation procedures for accounts in a past due status.  (ii) The policy should stipulate that the company will not accept central billing, direct invoicing nor provide cash advances for any employee who has had his/her corporate card cancelled for non-payment.
Finance charges or late fees on credit cards caused by associate's inaction are not reimbursable. Delinquent balances may lead to suspension or cancellation of account.
(i) Policy should advise employees that delinquency charges or late penalties on past due corporate card accounts are their personal responsibility and are not reimbursable.
Using personal credit cards for business travel expense is strictly prohibited. Personal credit card fees, late charges and interest are not reimbursable.

(i) If a personal credit card is used for travel and entertainment expenses, the policy should prohibit reimbursement for any annual fees, delinquency charges, interest charges, etc.  (ii) The best practice is for the policy to state that the use of a personal credit card is prohibited, unless a corporate card program is not established..

All expenses in foreign currency must be reported in local currency where transaction occurred and translated to originating local currency on expense report. Exchange rates should be taken from currency converter, credit card statement, bank exchange receipt or major financial newspapers.

(i) The policy should provide guidelines for accounting for the exchange rate for travel expenses incurred in currencies other than the currency of reimbursement; gains due to favorable exchange rate fluctuations should not accrue to the employee.  (ii) If a corporate card program is in place, the exchange rate used by the card provider should be the basis for the requested reimbursement amount.

VAT may be reclaimed for certain business expenses incurred overseas, particularly in Europe. Company submits applications for VAT refunds annually. Travelers must follow guidance of local Finance personnel for acceptable VAT reclaim documentation.
(I) The policy should indicate what documentation is required for VAT reclaims and under what circumstances claims can be made.
Rating is Null Because: Policy does not specify detailed VAT documentation requirements.Content: Need to add specific documentation requirements and circumstances for VAT claims.
Credit card membership programs on corporate card are considered personal benefit. Fees associated with these programs are not reimbursable.
(I) The policy should indicate that whether MRP's are a corporate-sponsored initiative or not and whether they are reimbursable.
Rating is Null Because: Policy does not clearly indicate if MRPs are corporate-sponsored.Content: Need to explicitly state whether MRPs are corporate-sponsored and reimbursement policy.
Business Calls and Faxes while Traveling

Associates will be reimbursed for reasonable phone charges when traveling if they don't have Gartner direct-billed mobile phone. While traveling, associates should use cell phone, laptop soft-phone or client provided services.

The policy states (i)  if charges for business calls while traveling are reimbursable; however, (ii) the employee will be encouraged to use the company's office phones for business-related calls as the most cost-effective alternative.
Rating is Null Because: Policy does not specifically encourage use of company office phones.Content: Need to add guidance promoting use of company office phones as most cost-effective option.

Mobile expenses are reimbursable up to threshold if mobile capability needed for business and not in country with direct bill program. Many countries use direct-billed mobile program where expenses should not be reimbursed through expense reporting or paid with corporate card.

The policy states if the company policy allows (i) guidelines for eligibility, approval requirements and how to obtain a company-provided device; (ii) preferred vendors for the device and monthly service; (iii) whether the hardware/equipment cost of the device is reimbursable or Company-provided; (iv) maximum monthly service reimbursement limits; (v) payment methods and expense reporting/documentation guidelines will be detailed, including a requirement to charge the monthly expenses to the corporate card, if available; (vi) the policy will state if insurance carried on the cell phone is reimbursable. (vii) Employees are advised to limit personal use of company-paid mobile devices.
Rating is Null Because: Policy lacks comprehensive mobile device guidelines.Content: Need to add detailed eligibility criteria, approval requirements, preferred vendors, and usage guidelines.
Business-Related Calls made from Personal Telephone Devices

Associates not on direct-billed company mobile program will be reimbursed for reasonable business calls if softphone/toll-free unavailable. Calls must be supported by original phone bill highlighting business calls.

The policy states: Business calls made from a personal telephone device will be addressed in the policy. (i) The policy will indicate under what circumstances costs will be reimbursed, required documentation and (ii) approval requirements.
Rating is Null Because: Policy does not specify approval requirements.Content: Need to add approval requirements for reimbursement of personal phone business calls.
For international travel, personal calls should be made via cost-effective methods like Skype, Facetime and other audio/video clients via Wi-Fi to avoid additional costs.

Certain mobile telephone plans do not include international destinations and the policy states (i) guidelines for alternatives to cell phone usage such as calling cards; (ii) if renting a cell phone is permissible and reimbursable.
Rating is Null Because: Policy does not address international phone alternatives.Content: Need to add guidelines for calling cards and cell phone rental options.
Expense reports must be submitted through Oracle i-Expense system. Expense reporting guidelines provided for meals classification and other categories.
The policy states (i)  indicate expense payment process. i.e. automated expense or paper-based solutions.  (ii) If a program is in place, a link or URL must be provided.

Detailed instructions provided for expense report submission including requirements for receipts, categorization, and supporting documentation. All expenses over $75 or client billable require receipts.

The policy states (i) Detailed instructions will be provided regarding how and to whom to submit travel-related expenses; (ii) required detail and documentation must be recorded and submitted in the corporate-approved format, a copy of which must be included in the policy document as either an appendix or reference to an on-line link.

Managers are required to review and approve/reject expenses in Oracle. Most senior ranking person should expense meals with other associates. Approving managers remain responsible for all approvals regardless of delegate being assigned.

(i) The policy should state clearly who in the organization is responsible for expense report approval; (ii) dollar value limits should be assigned to the management hierarchy and this matrix should be provided in the policy as either an appendix or within the body of the policy.

Expense reports must be completed within 15 days from date expense was charged to card. This may require separate reports for trips where airline ticket purchased significantly earlier than travel date.
Travel-related expenses must be accounted for in the correct accounting period to avoid misstatement and All the details regarding expense management is given on Tool
Original receipts required for all expenses over $75. For client billable engagements, receipts required regardless of amount. Copies of credit card slips alone not acceptable documentation per IRS.

The policy states (i)  original receipts/documents are required in all cases and (ii) indicate the type of documentation required for each expense type, i.e.., travel itineraries from the travel agency, management approval in ink, original invoices rather than credit card receipts, etc.
Expenses must be appropriately categorized in Oracle and should not be categorized as 'Other'. For lodging, costs must be broken out as separate line items daily (room/tax, meals, phone charges).

The policy states (i) To assist expense approvers and auditors in determining adherence to policy, the policy will require travelers to itemize all expenses by category rather than combine them into a daily total. This is especially important for hotel billings where meals, laundry and telecom expenses are typically part of the total.
All meals over $75 or international equivalent must have receipt. For client billable engagements, receipts required regardless of amount.
The policy states (i) It is recommended that the organization require receipts for all expenses of $25 or more.   The best in class position is to require receipts for expenses of $10 or more.
Reimbursement process and timing details not specifically outlined in policy document.

The policy states: The policy will provide clear instructions outlining the procedure for processing balances due the company and balances due the traveler after trip completion. (i) Reimbursement through electronic funds transfer or via payroll/bank deposit is an industry best practice and (ii) providing a commitment to reimburse within 5 days of receipt of expense claim an assurance to the traveler that funds will be available to settle accounts without the use of personal funds.
Rating is Null Because: Policy lacks reimbursement processing details.Content: Need to add clear instructions for processing reimbursement balances and timeline commitments.
Policy does not specifically address income tax implications of travel benefits.

The policy states (i) The policy will caution employees of their responsibility for income tax implications that may arise as a result of using employer-paid travel to earn points for personal-use travel or rewards or the reimbursement of expenses deemed to benefit the employee in any way.
Rating is Null Because: No mention of tax implications.Content: Need to add caution about tax implications of employer-paid travel benefits.
Government related expenses not specifically addressed in policy document.
The policy indicates: (i) All government expenses must be pre-approved by appropriate senior management or designated approver
Rating is Null Because: No mention of government expense requirements.Content: Need to add approval requirements for government-related expenses.
Meal limits are limits (not per diems) and vary according to destination as outlined in Appendix A.

The policy states (i) Per Diems will only be issued where there is a country requirement or with approval from senior management.  Employees who are eligible for Per Diems must not submit personal expenditures via the expense report.
Dependent care expenses not specifically addressed in policy document.
Guidelines for spending as they relate to employee travel should be provided but generally, (i) not a reimbursable expense or (i) reimbursable under specified, emergency-type circumstances.
Rating is Null Because: No mention of dependent care guidelines.Content: Need to add guidelines for dependent care expenses during travel.
Clothing, Luggage, Briefcase and Formal Attire Rental
Lost or stolen luggage and cost to replace personal items are sole responsibility of traveler. Expensive items should be left at home or placed in carry-on baggage.

Typically, not a reimbursable expense.  In extenuating circumstances, would require pre-approval.  Best practice is that this is only reimbursable under specified, emergency-type circumstances (i.e. winter coat for employees traveling to a destination which has weather condition to which the employee is not accustomed). Similarly for Luggage and Briefcases
Rating is Null Because: No mention of clothing/luggage reimbursement guidelines.Content: Need to add guidelines for emergency clothing/luggage expenses.
Computer privacy screen requirements not specifically addressed in policy document.
The policy states: Reimbursable for business purposes.  Best-practice is to encourage use to protect company information, especially in crowded areas such as on an airplane.
Rating is Null Because: No mention of computer privacy screens.Content: Need to add guidelines for privacy screen use and reimbursement.
Personal expenses like magazines, newspapers, toiletries not reimbursable except in case of lost baggage. Entertainment including event tickets not part of company event not reimbursable.

Magazines, Newspapers, Books and Subscriptions (unrelated to business) not reimbursableMassage, sauna, shoe shine and other personal services not reimbursable Personal Entertainment including event tickets (not part of a company-sponsored event) not reimbursableToiletries and other personal items - Typically, not a reimbursable expense except in case of lost baggage.
Administrative Services including use of hotel business center facilities, postage, courier, shipping/receiving personal property at Company location
Administrative services at hotel business centers are not specifically addressed in policy document.
Reimbursable if local office not available to provide such services._x000D_
Rating is Null Because: No mention of business center services.Content: Need to add guidelines for using hotel business center facilities.
Subscription reimbursement guidelines not specifically addressed in policy document.
Reimbursable for business-related publications.  Best practice is to have pre-approval.
Rating is Null Because: No mention of subscription guidelines.Content: Need to add guidelines for business-related publication subscriptions.
